Vol.Â VI

p1433 [Supplement, Vol.Â VI: 1910â1920]

(George Smith Patton,Â Jr., Born Nov.Â 11, 1885.)

Military History.Â â

Second Lieut., 15thÂ Cavalry, JuneÂ 11, 1909.

At Fort Sheridan,Â Ill., Sept.Â 11, 1909, to Dec.Â 19, 1911; at Fort Myer,Â Va., to JuneÂ 20, 1912: American contestant on Olympic Team in Modern Pentathlon; came out 4th against 43Â contestants; at Fort Myer,Â Va. Sept.Â 20, 1912, to JulyÂ 6, 1913; (detailed to design new cavalry saber, April,Â 1913); detailed to Saumur, France, to study French saber methods; left Fort Myer JulyÂ 6 and returned Sept.Â 15, 1913; at Ft.Â Riley,Â Kans., Master of the Sword, Mounted Service School, Sept.Â 20, 1913, to Sept.Â 15, 1915, when he was relieved by operation of the detached service law; (while at Fort Riley, graduated in first and second year courses, and wrote Saber Regulations, 1914); joined 15thÂ Cavalry at Fort Bliss, Texas;

(Transferred to 8thÂ Cavalry, Sept.Â 26, 1915)

at Fort Bliss and at Sierra Blanca, Texas, to MarchÂ 13, 1916; with Punitive Expedition into Mexico; entered Mexico as Acting Aide-deâCamp to General Pershing: commanded expedition of six men who attacked and killed General Julio Cardanes and two of his staff at SanÂ Miguelito, Mexico, MayÂ 16, 1916; (personally killed Cardanes and Garza);

(FirstÂ Lieut., 10thÂ Cavalry, MayÂ 23, 1916)

Â p1434Â returned to ElÂ Paso, Texas, on staff of General Pershing, Feb.Â 17, 1917; joined 7thÂ Cavalry at Camp Stewart, Texas, MarchÂ 3, 1917; detailed on Staff of Commanding General, A.Â E.Â F., MayÂ 12, 1917;

(Captain of Cavalry, MayÂ 15, 1917)

organized Hdqrs. Troop, MayÂ 22, 1917; enÂ route to England, MayÂ 28 to JuneÂ 8, 1917; Hdqrs. Troop billeted in Tower of London (first foreign troops ever accorded this honor); arrived in France JuneÂ 13, 1917; at Paris and at Chaumont, France, with General Hdqrs. A.Â E.Â F., to Nov.Â 17, 1917; first officer detailed in American Tank Corps, Nov.Â 17; at ChampÂ Lieu, France, taking course at French Tank School, Nov.Â 19 toÂ 30, 1917; at Battle of Cambrai, Dec.Â 1, 1917; organized Light Tank School at Langres, Dec.Â 17, 1917; appointed Director Army Tank School at Langres, Dec.Â 19, 1917; organized and commanded 302d Tank Center at Bourg, France;

(Major, Temporary, of Cavalry, Jan.Â 26, 1918)

present with French tanks in counter-attacks on Montdidier-Noyon front, MayÂ 15 to JuneÂ 2, 1918; took course and graduated from Army General Staff College at Langres; organized and commanded 304th Brigade Tank Corps; left Langres Aug.Â 22, 1918, to make reconnoissance for St.Â Mihiel Offensive; took part in that offensive, Sept.Â 12 toÂ 14; transferred to Argonne-Meuse Sector; commanded 304th Brigade Tank Corps in that offensive until wounded Sept.Â 26 near Cheppy, recommended for Distinguished Service Cross;

(Colonel, Tank Corps, Oct.Â 17, 1918)

released from Hospital Nov.Â 5, 1918, and resumed command of 304thÂ Brigade Tank Corps on same date; enÂ route toÂ U.Â S. in command of 304thÂ Brigade Tank Corps, MarchÂ 2 toÂ 17, 1919;

Awarded

Distinguished Service Cross

"For extraordinary heroism in action near Cheppy, France, SeptemberÂ 26, 1918. He displayed conspicuous courage, coolness, energy, and intelligence in directing the advance of his brigade down the valley of the Aire. Later he rallied a force of disorganized infantry and led it forward behind the tanks under heavy machineâgun and artillery fire until he was wounded. Unable to advance further, he continued to direct the operations of his unit until all arrangements for turning over the command were completed."

Awarded

Distinguished Service Medal

"For exceptionally meritorious and distinguished services. By his energy and sound judgment he rendered very valuable services in his organization and direction of the Tank Center at the Army schools in Langres. In the employment of Tank Corps troops in combat he displayed high military attainments, zeal, and marked adaptability in a form of warfare comparatively new to the American Army."

Military History:Â â

Distinguished Service Cross.

Distinguished Service Medal.

Colonel, Temporary, Tank Corps, Oct.Â 17, 1918.

EnÂ route toÂ U.Â S. in command of 304thÂ Brigade, Tank Corps, Mar.Â 2 toÂ 17, 1919; at Camp Meade,Â Md., commanding 304thÂ Brigade, Tank Corps, Mar.Â 18, 1919, to

Returned to Grade of Captain, JuneÂ 30, 1920.

Major of Cavalry, JulyÂ 1, 1920.

Sept.Â 19, 1920; at Fort Myer,Â Va., commanding 3rdÂ Squadron, 3rdÂ Cavalry, Sept.Â 21, 1920, to Nov.Â 20, 1922; at Fort Riley,Â Kans., student officer, Advanced Class, Cavalry School, Jan.Â 1, 1922, to JuneÂ 6, 1923; at Ft.Â Leavenworth,Â Kans., student officer, General Service Schools, Sept.Â 12, 1923, to JuneÂ 12, 1924, when he was graduated as an Honor Graduate; General Staff with troops, at Boston,Â Mass., Assistant Chief of Staff, Gâ1, 1stÂ Corps Area, July,Â 1924, to Mar.Â 4, 1925; at Honolulu,Â T.Â H., General Staff with Hawaiian division and HawaiianÂ Dept., Assistant Chief of Staff, Gâ1â2â3, Apr.,Â 1925, to Apr.,Â 1928; at Washington,Â D.Â C., Office, Chief of Cavalry, Plans and Training, Apr.Â 14, 1928, to Aug.Â 17, 1931; student officer, Army War College, Aug.Â 18, 1931, toÂ âââââ

Awarded Silver Star Citation.

Awarded Congressional Life Saving Medal of Honor. "In recognition of the gallant conduct displayed by him in assisting in rescuing three boys from drowning in Salem Harbor,Â Mass., Aug.Â 21, 1923."

At Washington,Â D.Â C., studentÂ off., A.Â W.Â C., Aug.Â 18, 1931 to JuneÂ 25, 1932; at Ft.Â Myer,Â Va., Executive Off., 3dÂ Cav., to

(Lt.âCol., Cav., Mar.Â 1, 1934)

Apr.Â 15, 1935; at Ft.Â Shafter, T.Â H., A.Â C.Â ofÂ S., Gâ2, HawaiianÂ Dept., MayÂ 21, 1935 to JulyÂ 12, 1937; at Ft.Â Riley,Â Kans., Director of Instruction, Cav.Â School, Aug.,Â 1937 to

(Col., Cav., JulyÂ 1, 1938)

July,Â 1938; at Fort Clark,Â Tex., comdg. 5thÂ Cav., to Dec.,Â 1938; at Ft.Â Myer,Â Va., comdg. 3dÂ Cav., to July,Â 1940; at Ft.Â Benning,Â Ga., comdg. 2dÂ Brig. 2dÂ ArmoredÂ Div., JulyÂ 16, 1940 toÂ âââââ

14Â JanÂ 42; CG 1Â Armd Corps, 15Â Jan-31Â MarÂ 42; CpÂ Young Calif, CG 1Â Armd Corps, 1Â Apr-5Â AugÂ 42; ETO, CG London Base Comd, 6Â Aug-7Â NovÂ 42; NATO, CGÂ WesternÂ TF, 2Â Armd Corps, 1Â Armd Corps, Seventh Army (Sicily), 8Â NovÂ 42â

(Lt Gen AUS 12Â MarÂ 43)

(GenÂ AUS 26Â AprÂ 45)

6Â OctÂ 45; CGÂ Fifteenth USÂ Army in American-occupied Germany, 7Â Oct-21Â DecÂ 45.

Died, Dec.Â 21, 1945, at Heidelberg, Germany: AgedÂ 60.
